annotations: I, I cry like crocodile

Crookes refers to the phrase crocodile tears, which means a false display of sincerity. This is probably to demonstrate the persona, which she’s writing from, of someone who has not cared much about social justice before, displaying empathy that might not be genuine.

I’ve been posing with red skies
 Retweeting picket signs
 Put my name on petitions, but I won’t change my mind

The theme of “Feet Don’t Fail Me Now” stemmed from the plethora of political protests that swept the globe in 2020, with Crookes writing the song from the perspective of someone who doesn’t speak up and spread awareness as much as they know they can. During an August 2021 interview with PhilStar, Crookes expanded more on what inspired the opening lines:

I wrote [“Feet Don’t Fail Me Now”] after we had many protests in London, and I know that America had many protests last year. Obviously, after the kind of uproar of the Black Lives Matter (BLM) movement and criminal injustice in general, injustice in America, in the UK, I think naturally people had had enough. […] And we took to the streets over the summer. I mean, I’ve never really protested that much before in my life, but all of us, every single one of my friends and I were out there protesting. And I thought it was a very interesting time because many people were either pretending that they really, suddenly cared… I know from being brown my whole life that this person may have never cared about race before, and they were just caring so it’d make them look good, or they were saying nothing at all. […] And so, this song is me playing a very ironic character that is saying, ‘Oh, you know, I like posing with the signs from the protests and I like retweeting stuff online, but nothing is changing here.’ So this is a character that finds it much easier to say nothing because they’re scared of what the consequences of speaking out will be.”

annotations:
Spending nights in lonely castles
 Where I learned to sing my cries

Speaking with Vogue, Crookes explained the meaning behind these lyrics:

I started writing songs when I was sad at home. I was 12 and I learned to pick up the guitar and instead of sitting in my bed crying, I learned to sing my cries.

“When You Were Mine” is the third single off of Crookes' upcoming debut album, Skin.

It was first performed at a secret gig at the Milk Float in Hackney Wick, London, on the 23rd of August, 2021.

annotatable.link_title: When You Were Mine by Joy Crookes
annotatable.title: When You Were Mine

body.plain:
“When You Were Mine” is the third single off of Crookes' upcoming debut album, Skin.

It was first performed at a secret gig at the Milk Float in Hackney Wick, London, on the 23rd of August, 2021.

annotations: Coldharbour Lane
Road in Brixton in South London
Never take it easy on the PDA

PDA is a common abbreviation for a Public Display of Affection. In this context, Joy’s ex and his new partner are making no efforts to hide their infatuation with each other.

The following lines explain how Joy does not miss the intimacy she shared with her ex because she’s glad that he’s found happiness, but she does hope that one day she can find that same happiness for herself.
Thirty-five
The 35 is a public Transport for London bus route which passes through parts of Brixton.
J.D. and cola

J.D. is an abbreviation of the Tennessee whiskey Jack Daniels.



When combined with 3 to 5 parts of cola, the aforementioned cocktail is made.

I’m shook, but you look good together
 I had my hesitation, but I just can’t hate him

During an October 2021 interview with BBC, Crookes commented on the joking manner of this line:


When You Were Mine is about my first love, who got in a gay relationship with another man after we broke up.

It’s like, “I’m shook but you look good together and I’m proud of you.” It’s a little bit of jealousy and it’s a celebration of their love.

I don’t miss you, least not that way
 But someone better want me like that someday

During an August 2021 interview with Bricks Magazine, Crookes reflected on the ways in which nostalgia has inspired her throughout her songwriting career. While Skin covers a multitude of nostalgic topics – both positive and negative – “When You Were Mine” sees Crookes reflect back on a past relationship she wishes she could replicate in a future one.

Crookes further expanded on her innate pull to using nostalgia as a source of inspiration, adding:

I think I spend 96% of my life reminiscing. Nostalgia is… it’s what we said earlier, it’s a longing to belong, right? I feel like that’s just my kind of sandwich. That’s who I am. My memory is ridiculous; I can go to places I went to when I was eight or nine and remember streets and where the library is and this, that and the other. I think it’s just fundamentally a part of my blood to be nostalgic, and to long for something because I actually get a lot of kick out of longing for things. Maybe that’s quite a Bollywood part of me, I don’t know.”

Crookes' 2019 track “Darkest Hour” demonstrates the nostalgia she holds for her childhood, writing about her father who always led her on the right path:

Motorola was the pebble phone
And all your cigarettes were Marlboro
Orange shadows on the way back home
All the memories our castle holds
When heavy hearts were not unusual
I’d have to meet you at the corner shop
All the years that I spent indigo
My father’s arms were indestructible

description.plain:
“Early” is the first collaboration between Irish hip-hop artist Jafaris and Irish R&B singer Joy Crookes.

Crookes first teased the collaboration in April 2019, posting a video to her Instagram of the two singing a demo version of the track in Crookes' home studio. Crookes later responded to a fan comment and confirmed it would be released “soon.”

The duo continued to tease the release by posting pictures from the track’s music video, which was filmed in Crookes' grandmothers' home in Ireland.

On October 3rd, 2019, both artists confirmed that “Early” would be released the following day, October 4th.



  Jafaris and Joy Crookes shooting the cover art in 2019

song.title: Early

body.plain:
“Early” is the first collaboration between Irish hip-hop artist Jafaris and Irish R&B singer Joy Crookes.

Crookes first teased the collaboration in April 2019, posting a video to her Instagram of the two singing a demo version of the track in Crookes' home studio. Crookes later responded to a fan comment and confirmed it would be released “soon.”

The duo continued to tease the release by posting pictures from the track’s music video, which was filmed in Crookes' grandmothers' home in Ireland.

On October 3rd, 2019, both artists confirmed that “Early” would be released the following day, October 4th.



  Jafaris and Joy Crookes shooting the cover art in 2019

description.plain:
“Yah / Element (Medley)” sees Joy Crookes with much slower and soulful cover of American rapper Kendrick Lamar’s two songs “YAH.” and “ELEMENT.”.

Crookes hinted on September 11th, 2019 that new music was coming “sooner than you think” in a tweet, alongside a picture from what appeared to be a behind-the-scenes of a music video. In the picture, Crookes is driving with a cutout of Lamar.

description.plain:
“You & Me Song” was featured in a September 2020 advertisement for UK Internet network company O2 and is a cover of The Wannadies‘ 1994 original version. On September 12, Crookes posted the advertisement to her social medias, adding:

I went from buying o2 phone credit for my blackberry to singing on their adverts. Nuts. Thank you [@]o2

description.plain: “Mother May I Sleep With Danger” is the fourth track on Joy’s Influence EP. She popularized the song when she performed it on the YouTube show COLORS which is a popular avenue for new artists to perform their music. The lyrics provided suit the EP version of the song, differing slightly from the COLORS version.

annotations: [Verse 2]

Crookes told The Line of Best Fit:

And then in second verse when “I’m runnin' through East Street with emotional baggage,” it reveals that this guy I fall in love with just so happens to have been through all the stuff that I’ve been through, so he’s clearly reminiscing, too.
[Pre-Chorus]

Crookes told The Line of Best Fit:

… it comes to the chorus, the present, which is the message of the song; just because I’ve had to deal with these fucking wastemen, all trying to use me for sex or whatever, or even myself using other men…I’m in the present now, I’ve cleared it up in verse one, baby, and I’m ready to go!
[Verse 1]

Crookes told The Line of Best Fit:

All of the first verse is past, then it comes to the chorus, the present, which is the message of the song.

song.embed_content: Read “Trouble” by Joy Crookes on Genius
song.title: Trouble

annotations: Running your mouth with that malarkey
Malarkey means nonsensical and meaningless talk; Crookes believes her arguments with her family member and of theirs is nonsensical and meaningless to do.

You’re all that I need
 But we break every time
 Birds of feather fly together
 Your trouble’s the same as mine

Crookes knows that they are all they need, yet they always argue.

“Birds of a feather fly together” is a phrase meaning that people with the same interests tend to mutually associate with each other more. In this case, Crookes mutually associates herself with the family member, yet they also have the same troubles and flaws and hurt each other.
I’m Villanelle to your Sandra Oh

This line is a reference to the TV show ‘Killing Eve’, with the two protagonists (Villanelle, Jodie Comer and Eve, Sandra Oh) chasing each other around like cat and mouse. The relationship is broken, but it’s clear they need each other really.
